title: Teen who asked pop band Five Star 'Why are you so f***ing c**p?' refuses to apologise
text:

A man who flung expletives at the 80s pop group Five Star during a BBC children’s show as a teenager has refused to apologise.

The man, who claims to be the same Eliot Fletcher who got through to the band during an episode of the BBC Saturday morning Going Live, said he holds no regrets about his savage outburst in the prank phone call more than 30 years ago.

In the live on-air call, a teenage Eliot had asked the band: “Why are you so f**king crap?”

His naughty call got him into trouble with his mum, who came home a little while later to a furious BBC executive on the phone demanding her son apologise.

During an investigation by the BBC’s Mark Savage into the now infamous rant, a man claiming to be the same Eliot Fletcher revealed why he did it.

“The thing was, I was a big fan of theirs. Then all of a sudden, they were on TV showing off their new Ferraris, and the music started going down hill. So as a young kid who took their music very seriously, I felt like they were selling out,” he told the BBC.

“I didn't know I was going to swear or anything. I just knew I wanted to get on there and give them a piece of my teenage mind.”

Five Star had been on the show to promote their 18th single With Every Heartbeat, and were shocked to hear young Eliot’s expletive-ridden question.

(Image: Getty Images)

However, the adult Eliot insists he has nothing to apologise for.

“No apologies. What’s done is done. As an adult you kind of feel slightly different about it, but the child in me is like, ‘No’,” he went on.

“No regrets at all. It's funny listening to it now, because I do sound really, really angry. I think that's why it stuck in people's minds.”

However, a second man claiming to be Eliot Fletcher cropped up two weeks ago on Twitter to apologise for the outburst to Five Star singer Doris Pearson, who graciously accepted - and even asked him out for a pint to settle the matter.

But this Eliot’s identity could not be verified - although Doris didn’t seem to mind either way.

"You know, it was so many moons ago, and I'm a forgiving gal," she added to the BBC.

”And to be honest, all I thought at the time was, 'Well, we're actually not crap'."
description: Speaking more than 30 years on, the man says he holds no regrets about his savage outburst in the prank phone call
